body:
Similarly if I use `play.ws.ssl.hostnameVerifierClass=myutil.play.DisabledHostnameVerifier` - the class is instantiated, but never called. 

``` scala
class DisabledHostnameVerifier extends HostnameVerifier {

  Logger.info("Instantiating DisabledHostnameVerifier")

  override def verify(hostname: String, sslSession: SSLSession): Boolean = {
    Logger.info(s"Verifying $hostname as true!")
    true
  }
}
```


issue.title: Custom HostnameVerifier never called, connection prematurely rejected

repository.name: async-http-client
repository.description: Asynchronous Http and WebSocket Client library for Java

issue.body:
See https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/issues/927 and https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/4796 

I need to customize the hostname checks for some requests to localhost, so I've tried injecting a custom HostnameVerifier, but the Sun HostnameChecker causes an exception without ever calling my code. 

This may be caused by the fix to https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/issues/927 where the sslEngine is told to use "HTTPS" as the endpoint verification algorithm, [see this line](https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/blob/cdcd4d7e747c924c1d0ba6afa000776f8dd37921/src/main/java/com/ning/http/client/SSLEngineFactory.java#L55).

body:
Turns out the AsyncHttpClientConfig.Builder.setHostnameVerifier() method has been removed from async-http-client in master, presumably because it didn't actually work. 

I guess that means this particular configuration option will eventually be removed from Play?
@jxtps async-http-client master is way ahead of Play 2.4.x
Wasn't this taken care of with https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/issues/197 ?

@jxtps Can you put together a reproducible test case project?  I'd like to poke at things, but I don't know why you're looking at AHC master.

Also, it DID work at one point -- see https://tersesystems.com/2014/03/31/testing-hostname-verification/ for details.

I'm not using ACH master, I just looked there when @slandelle said he didn't know of a way to plug in a custom HostnameVerifier. Since it was gone there, I assumed it to be deprecated functionality. I'm using vanilla Play 2.4.1 (so whatever it pulls in when adding a dependency on ws). 

My code is super-simple, it just does a regular WS get, but with hostname verification disabled (`play.ws.ssl.loose.disableHostnameVerification=true`). 

Set that in your application.conf, and then do e.g. 

``` scala
import scala.concurrent.ExecutionContext.Implicits.global
WS.url("https://74.125.239.48").
  withVirtualHost("www.google.com").
  get().map(response => Logger.info("Hello Google! " + response.status + ", " + response.body.take(1024))).
  recover {
  case ex: Exception => Logger.info("Failed!", ex)
}
```

(code excerpt from my comment on https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/issues/927 )

In the event google changes their servers, `nslookup www.google.com`

Right... so.  AHC 1.8.15, if you look at NettyConnectListener, the operationComplete() method has a call out to the hostname verifier.

http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/com.ning/async-http-client/1.8.15/com/ning/http/client/providers/netty/NettyConnectListener.java#75

In AHC 1.9.x, it does not.  http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/com.ning/async-http-client/1.9.15/com/ning/http/client/providers/netty/request/NettyConnectListener.java#NettyConnectListener.operationComplete%28org.jboss.netty.channel.ChannelFuture%29

So when Play upgraded to AHC 1.9.x, this functionality was lost.
@wsargent Passing a HostnameVerifier is still in the 1.9.x API because of the JDK provider (that goes away in AHC2).
okay, well... either setEndpointIdentificationAlgorithm is set or it's not, but it doesn't look like there's a custom option now.

You can see it's still calling the HostnameChecker under X509ExtendedTrustManager, but there's not an easy way to get at it.  

http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/8u40-b25/sun/security/ssl/X509TrustManagerImpl.java#455

Looks like hacking directly into the trust manager is the only way.

issue.title: Wip/reactive streams with ahc 2

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
- Bumped async-http-client version to 2.0.0-alpha11 (which adds reactive stream support).
- Decommissioned  enabling/disabling of hostname verification (@wsargent @jroper please have a look at this) and updated documentation.
- Forcing shutdown of ~~both netty and~~ ahc event loop.
- Updated WS response's streaming to use AHC reactive stream support.

body: So in play 2.4 there is no way to have this working? Anyone found a workaround for play 2.4?
I am experiencing this issue as well, Play 2.4.3.

You can configure the underlying AsyncHttpClient instance with System props: https://github.com/AsyncHttpClient/async-http-client/blob/1.9.x/src/main/java/com/ning/http/client/AsyncHttpClientConfigDefaults.java#L109

Adding -Dcom.ning.http.client.AsyncHttpClientConfig.acceptAnyCertificate=true actually did not work for me - Though doing:
      val config=new AsyncHttpClientConfigBean()
      config.setAcceptAnyCertificate(true)
      val client=new NingWSClient(config)
works - Come to think of it this is a 'better/safer' way of doing this...

> Adding -Dcom.ning.http.client.AsyncHttpClientConfig.acceptAnyCertificate=true did not work for me

My2cents: you passed the system prop to the sbt JVM instead of the application one
I even debugged it - the option is set... Maybe play is explicitely setting that config. Regardless I actually prefer to create a client 'by hand'
